title: A really beautiful roman sure you all know...
content:
... but not me.

thanks in advance

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022032915im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HUO_brief_01_4724.jpg)
author: carlos_moreno_

comments.content:
Genath, designed by François Rappo.

If you would have done a search first you would have found \* [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022032915/http:/typophile.com/node/54725)\*.
To make searching a success it’s of course necessary to [use a descriptive title! Thank you.](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022032915/http:/typophile.com/forum/typeid/faq/#Q_2)

Sorry, I'm new to this and don't manage quite well. Next time I'll search before asking ;)  
Ditto for the descriptive title.

Thanks a lot

hi, how to start new subject...  
sorry I'm new here :)

The typeface Genath reminded me of something better-known, and I suspect the person posting the query had thought it was one of the common standby typefaces listed in the normal references like Perpetua, Garamond, Lutetia, and so on.

In looking for more information, I came across [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/nonpareille/stockmar/ Stockmar](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022032915/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/nonpareille/stockmar/%20Stockmar) and [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/type-together/maiola/ Maiola](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022032915/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/type-together/maiola/%20Maiola)... so many beautiful typefaces go unnoticed.

However, I've found _another_ typeface that has the same kind of unusual italic "r" as this one. Starling. (Obviously this isn't Starling; the lowercase "a", for example, is much too much an oldstyle one.)
